title: Today in Apple history: Steve Jobs loses ‘Man of the Year’ award to the PC
description: On December 26, 1982, "Time" magazine named the personal computer its "Machine of the Year." The news devastated Steve Jobs. (via Cult of Mac - Apple news, rumors, reviews and how-tos)
author: Luke Dormehl
excerpt: On December 26, 1982, "Time" magazine named the personal computer its "Machine of the Year." The news devastated Steve Jobs.
text: Apple history Steve Jobs was devastated by the announcement. Photo: Time magazine December 26, 1982: Time magazine names the personal computer its “Man of the Year.” It’s the first time a nonhuman entity wins the award, which was created in 1927. And the award devastates Steve Jobs — because he thought the accolade would go to him. Time named the PC its ‘Machine of the Year’ in 1983 Time magazine’s annual “Man of the Year” or “Woman of the Year” award typically saluted the biggest newsmakers of the past 12 months. However, in 1983, the magazine switched things up to honor the first “Machine of the Year”  with an issue that hit newsstands on December 26. (Its cover date showed the following week, January 3, 1983, in case you’re wondering about the timing of this installment of “Today in Apple history.”) The award highlighted how far personal computers had come in just a few years, not just technologically but also as a world-changing industry. Apple, only 5 years old at the time, had not yet released the Macintosh. However, the Apple II was phenomenally successful. Apple was also on the verge of launching the Lisa, its first machine to offer a graphical user interface and mouse. Personal computing: A growing industry A niche industry for nerdy hobbyists just a few years earlier, by 1981 a massive 1.4 million home computers were sold in the United States. The following year, that number doubled. Alongside Apple’s offerings, other influential early computers included the Commodore PET and, most notably, the IBM PC, which proved to be Apple’s biggest competitor. Apple co-founder Steve Jobs was no stranger to Time magazine. In February 1982, he appeared on the cover as part of a feature on young entrepreneurs. The article stated that Jobs “practically singlehanded created the personal computer industry.” It also noted that, despite Apple’s humble beginnings in a garage, the company was “expected to have sales of $600 million” in 1982. Jobs’ role as having invented the industry “singlehanded” was hyperbolic. However, it’s easy to see why Jobs felt he was in line for “Man of the Year” in 1982. Particularly so after he heard that the award would go to someone involved in the home computer market. Years later, he remained enraged that he did not receive the accolade he felt he deserved. Steve Jobs felt snubbed by Time’s pick As Jobs told his biographer Walter Isaacson: “Time decided they were going to make me Man of the Year, and I was 27, so I actually cared about stuff like that. I thought it was pretty cool. They sent out [journalist and later venture capitalist] Mike Moritz to write a story. We’re the same age, and I had been very successful, and I could tell he was jealous and there was an edge to him. He wrote this terrible hatchet job. So the editors in New York get this story and say, ‘We can’t make this guy Man of the Year.’ That really hurt. But it was a good lesson. It taught me to never get too excited about things like that, since the media is a circus anyway. They FedExed me the magazine, and I remember opening the package, thoroughly expecting to see my mug on the cover, and it was this computer sculpture thing. I thought, ‘Huh?’ And then I read the article, and it was so awful that I actually cried.” Isaacson denies that Time ever considered Jobs for the “Man of the Year” award. And so does Ray Cave, then the magazine’s editor. However, the feeling certainly stayed with Jobs. Years later, in a position to avoid the press and more tightly control his personal image, Jobs became obsessed with controlling the Apple narrative.
html:
• Apple history

December 26, 1982: Time magazine names the personal computer its “Man of the Year.”

It’s the first time a nonhuman entity wins the award, which was created in 1927. And the award devastates Steve Jobs — because he thought the accolade would go to him.

Time named the PC its ‘Machine of the Year’ in 1983

Time magazine’s annual “Man of the Year” or “Woman of the Year” award typically saluted the biggest newsmakers of the past 12 months. However, in 1983, the magazine switched things up to honor the first “Machine of the Year”  with an issue that hit newsstands on December 26. (Its cover date showed the following week, January 3, 1983, in case you’re wondering about the timing of this installment of “Today in Apple history.”)

The award highlighted how far personal computers had come in just a few years, not just technologically but also as a world-changing industry. Apple, only 5 years old at the time, had not yet released the Macintosh. However, the Apple II was phenomenally successful. Apple was also on the verge of launching the Lisa, its first machine to offer a graphical user interface and mouse.

Personal computing: A growing industry

A niche industry for nerdy hobbyists just a few years earlier, by 1981 a massive 1.4 million home computers were sold in the United States. The following year, that number doubled. Alongside Apple’s offerings, other influential early computers included the Commodore PET and, most notably, the IBM PC, which proved to be Apple’s biggest competitor.

Apple co-founder Steve Jobs was no stranger to Time magazine. In February 1982, he appeared on the cover as part of a feature on young entrepreneurs. The article stated that Jobs “practically singlehanded created the personal computer industry.” It also noted that, despite Apple’s humble beginnings in a garage, the company was “expected to have sales of $600 million” in 1982.

Jobs’ role as having invented the industry “singlehanded” was hyperbolic. However, it’s easy to see why Jobs felt he was in line for “Man of the Year” in 1982. Particularly so after he heard that the award would go to someone involved in the home computer market. Years later, he remained enraged that he did not receive the accolade he felt he deserved.

Steve Jobs felt snubbed by Time’s pick

As Jobs told his biographer Walter Isaacson:

“Time decided they were going to make me Man of the Year, and I was 27, so I actually cared about stuff like that. I thought it was pretty cool. They sent out [journalist and later venture capitalist] Mike Moritz to write a story. We’re the same age, and I had been very successful, and I could tell he was jealous and there was an edge to him. He wrote this terrible hatchet job. So the editors in New York get this story and say, ‘We can’t make this guy Man of the Year.’ That really hurt. But it was a good lesson. It taught me to never get too excited about things like that, since the media is a circus anyway. They FedExed me the magazine, and I remember opening the package, thoroughly expecting to see my mug on the cover, and it was this computer sculpture thing. I thought, ‘Huh?’ And then I read the article, and it was so awful that I actually cried.”

Isaacson denies that Time ever considered Jobs for the “Man of the Year” award. And so does Ray Cave, then the magazine’s editor. However, the feeling certainly stayed with Jobs.

Years later, in a position to avoid the press and more tightly control his personal image, Jobs became obsessed with controlling the Apple narrative.
